Title.evidence: The STRAUSS Study: A Randomised Controlled Trial on the Effect of Music on Surgical Stress

Trial_Design.evidence: This non-blinded, randomised crossover trial was conducted at the University of Auckland from April to October 2023.

Participants.evidence: Participants included 15 medical students and 12 vascular surgeons. Eligibility criteria excluded those with significant physical impairments, pregnancy, cardiac history, or hearing impairments.

Intervention.evidence: Participants performed a carotid patch-angioplasty under two conditions: self-selected music and ambient theatre noise (control).

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the psycho-physiological effects of music on stress in inexperienced and experienced operators during a simulated surgical task.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the effect of music on psychological (STAI-6, SURG-TLX) and physiological responses (heart rate variability) measured immediately post-task.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was by coin toss, with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: This non-blinded, randomised crossover trial was conducted at the University of Auckland from April to October 2023. Participants included 15 medical students and 12 vascular surgeons.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Experienced operators performed faster and more accurately, with no differential response to music.

Result_Outcome.evidence: SURG-TLX scores increased from baseline to control (Δ32 [22–42]) and music (Δ30 [20–40]), with no difference between conditions. STAI-6 scores increased similarly. Heart rate increased (peak Δ5.1 bpm [3.0–7.1], p < 0.0001), with music exacerbating sympathetic (SNS index: 0.14 [0.004–0.27], p = 0.042) and reducing parasympathetic activity (PNS index: −0.11 [−0.22 to −0.008], p = 0.032).
